awd_abstract_narration:
Recent observations of our own Sun as well as other stars suggest the need for new approach to modeling stellar evolution, which fully takes into account the inevitably magnetized nature of stars.  Dr. Pascale Garaud (University of California - Santa Cruz) will work on the construction of a multidimensional stellar evolution model which takes into account magnetic fields, rotation and all other associated dynamical effects.  As a part of this project a new numerical model developed which couples the exact solutions of the nuclear evolution equations to a dynamical magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model for the internal flows and fields on the larger scales, and a well-tested and experimentally calibrated turbulent MHD closure model for the smaller scales. This new work is a natural extension of Dr. Garaud's ongoing research on the MHD structure of stellar interiors.

Dr. Garaud and her collaborators will also launch a yearly international Summer School and Workshop in Astrophysical Fluid Dynamics (AFD). The lecture series will be loosely modeled on the world-renowned Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Summer School hosted by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. The lectures will be focused on teaching students the theoretical (mathematical and computational) tools for certain classes of problems in AFD. A related scientific workshop will be organized at the end of each lecture series inviting this time both theorists and observers, thus completing the program with a state-of-the art dual perspective in the topic studied.  The venue will alternate between different partner countries to enhance the international dimension of the program and share organizational costs. The lectures will be published on the web.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: 

This research project was concerned with understanding the life of stars, and the effect magnetic fields have on their evolution. Based on recent observations of the Sun, scientists know that it is most likely permeated by magnetic fields on both large and small scales, from the surface all the way down to its core. The same is likely true for other stars as well. These core magnetic fields can upset the sensitive balance of forces deep within the star and drive plasma motions on very large scales. These motions can in turn transport chemical elements from the core to the surface, which affects the star in two ways: (1) by bringing the ashes of nuclear reactions to the surface, they change the surface chemical composition of the star, in a way that can in pricinple be observed. (2) by bringing fresh fuel to the core, they rejuvenate the star and can in principle prolong its life. 

The PI and her team have dediated these 5 years to quantifying the interaction between the plasma motions and the magnetic field, in order to better understand their impact on the stars life. Using a combination of state-of-the-art numerical simulations and pen-and-paper or blackboard calculations, they have discovered that four factors  are particularly important: the star's magnetic field strength, naturally, but also the star's rotation rate, the rate of diffusion of fields and heat  and finally, the rate at which density decreases outward (called the stratification). In fact, they have identifed a number of possible regimes depending the values of relative combinations of these four factors, which all have very different behavior in terms of the transport of chemical species from the core to the surface, and in terms of the manner in which the star rotates (i.e. nearly like a solid body, despite being a plasma, or mostly differentially from the core to the surface). While this work was so far quite theoretical, the PI is now hoping to apply her findings to stellar observations, to determine whether the predictions made by her models can indeed provide a more accurate undertstanding of stars than what had so far been possible. 

Broader impacts:

Thanks to NSF funding, the PI created a new international summer program in astrophysics where graduate students, postdocs and faculty come together to solve topical outstanding problems. It was run in 2010, 2011 and 2014, and will be run again this year (2016).  The program is a huge success, by all measures. It has given students the opportunity to dive into a new astrophysical research field and interact with the scientific leaders of that field. Many discoveries have been made, in part thanks to the interdisciplinary nature of the program, and in part thanks to the excellence and dedication of all the participants involved. 

As of this year, we have an excellent opportunity to secure permanent partial funding for the program thanks to a very significant philantropic gift from the Kavli Foundation. We are therefore hoping to offer the program every year from now on, alternating between venues in Santa Cruz and world-wide.
